name: Hotel Room 206
description: A perfectly ordinary hotel room that's trying very hard to be unremarkable and almost succeeds. The bed is regulation hotel-firm, the pillows are regulation puffy, and the art on the walls depicts regulation seascapes of beaches you'll never visit. What makes the room interesting is what it's missing: no television, no telephone, no clock. Just a bed, a dresser, a chair, and a profound silence that fills the space like acoustic insulation. The window looks out onto an air shaft, providing a view of other windows, behind which other guests presumably lead lives of quiet desperation.

features.silence: The absence of mechanical hums and electronic buzzing creates a void that your ears keep trying to fill with imaginary sounds.
features.window: Overlooks the air shaft, a vertical canyon of brick and other people's bathroom windows. A pigeon on the ledge judges you silently.
features.simplicity: No TV means you're left with your thoughts. No clock means time moves at its own pace. No phone means you're unreachable. This is either zen or a nightmare.
features.seascapes: Three framed prints of beaches: one at dawn, one at noon, one at sunset. A complete narrative arc of sand.
